dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, good news on Wednesday, right? After a pretty wild week, the markets actually saw some decent gains. Dow was up like, 1.6 percent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, good news on Wednesday, right? After a pretty wild week, the markets actually saw some decent gains. Dow was up like, one point six percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 1.6%, around 450 points, on Wednesday, while the S&P 500 rose 1.8% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite gained 1.9%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, absolutely! I mean, after Tuesday's bloodbath, it was, uh, a welcome sight. The S&P 500 rose almost 2%, and, like, the tech-heavy Nasdaq? Also up big, around 1.9%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, absolutely! I mean, after Tuesday's bloodbath, it was, uh, a welcome sight. The S and P five hundred rose almost two percent, and, like, the tech-heavy Nasdaq? Also up big, around one point nine percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 1.6%, around 450 points, on Wednesday, while the S&P 500 rose 1.8% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite gained 1.9%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it looks like a lot of those big tech players, you know, Microsoft, Amazon, Facebook, Google's parent company Alphabet, they all actually bounced back pretty nicely.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it looks like a lot of those big tech players, you know, Microsoft, Amazon, Facebook, Google's parent company Alphabet, they all actually bounced back pretty nicely.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Tech stocks rebounded somewhat, a day after the Nasdaq fell into correction territory, with shares of Microsoft, Amazon, Facebook and Google-parent Alphabet all moving higher.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they did. And, uh, you know who else? Tesla! After having its *worst day ever* on Tuesday, like, down 21% from the S&P snub? It popped over 5% yesterday.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they did. And, uh, you know who else? Tesla! After having its worst day ever on Tuesday, like, down twenty one percent from the S and P snub? It popped over five percent yesterday.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Teslas stock, which had its worst day ever on Tuesdayfalling 21% after being snubbed from the S&P 500 index, rose over 5% on Wednesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Oh, that was insane! I was watching that. And Apple too, it had been hammered, uh, down 14% over three days, but it rebounded over 3% yesterday.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that was insane! I was watching that. And Apple too, it had been hammered, uh, down fourteen percent over three days, but it rebounded over three percent yesterday.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Shares of Apple, which fell 14% in the previous three sessions, also rebounded on Wednesday, gaining over 3%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild, isn't it? And investors also kinda shrugged off that AstraZeneca vaccine setback, you know, with the mysterious illness in the UK patient. Didn't seem to faze them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild, isn't it? And investors also kinda shrugged off that AstraZeneca vaccine setback, you know, with the mysterious illness in the U K patient. Didn't seem to faze them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Investors also shrugged off a setback with AstraZeneca and Oxfords late-stage coronavirus vaccine, which has now been put on hold due to a patient in the U.K. coming down with a mysterious illness.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: That's interesting, given how much attention vaccine news usually gets. But then you have these oddballs, like, Lululemon and Slack, both reported *better* than expected earnings, yet their shares still fell pretty hard? Over 7% and 14% respectively.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's interesting, given how much attention vaccine news usually gets. But then you have these oddballs, like, Lululemon and Slack, both reported better than expected earnings, yet their shares still fell pretty hard? Over seven percent and fourteen percent respectively.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Despite both companies reporting better-than-expected corporate earnings, shares of athletic retailer Lululemon and workplace messaging platform Slack fell more than 7% and 14%, respectively.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that was, uh, definitely a head-scratcher. But it kinda feeds into what Adam Crisafulli from Vital Knowledge said. He called Wednesday's rally "simply a bounce from oversold conditions."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that was, uh, definitely a head-scratcher. But it kinda feeds into what Adam Crisafulli from Vital Knowledge said. He called Wednesday's rally simply a bounce from oversold conditions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Wednesdays rally is simply a bounce from oversold conditions but investors shouldnt anticipate a V-shaped move right back to the highs, says Vital Knowledge founder Adam Crisafulli.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: So, wait, he's saying don't get too excited? Like, it's not a V-shaped recovery straight back to the highs?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, wait, he's saying don't get too excited? Like, it's not a V-shaped recovery straight back to the highs?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. He thinks the sentiment around tech, um, isn't really conducive to forming a *sustainable* bottom. Basically, if people are asking *when* to buy, not *if*, then these bounces? They should probably be sold, not chased.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. He thinks the sentiment around tech, um, isn't really conducive to forming a sustainable bottom. Basically, if people are asking when to buy, not if, then these bounces? They should probably be sold, not chased.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If anything, sentiment around tech isnt conducive to forming a sustainable bottom with most people asking when (not if) the group should be bought as a result, bounces right now should be sold, not chased.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. So, it's almost like, uh, take the money and run? Because, let's not forget, this "bounce" came after a pretty brutal stretch, right? The tech sell-off had been going on for a bit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. So, it's almost like, uh, take the money and run? Because, let's not forget, this bounce came after a pretty brutal stretch, right? The tech sell-off had been going on for a bit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The tech sell-off which started last week continued on Tuesday, dragging the market lower as investors once again rotated out of hot Nasdaq stocks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. The tech sell-off started last week, and then Tuesday was just brutal. That's when the Nasdaq officially entered correction territory, like, down 10% in just *three days*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. The tech sell-off started last week, and then Tuesday was just brutal. That's when the Nasdaq officially entered correction territory, like, down ten percent in just three days.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Following the sharp losses, the Nasdaq officially entered correction territory, falling 10% in just three days of trading.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I remember last Thursday too, the market had its worst day since June. Dow was down over 800 points, S&P 500 lost more than 3%, and the Nasdaq, uh, over 5%. Wild times.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I remember last Thursday too, the market had its worst day since June. Dow was down over eight hundred points, S and P five hundred lost more than three percent, and the Nasdaq, uh, over five percent. Wild times.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Investors first began rotating out of tech stocks last Thursday, causing stocks to retreat from record highs as the market posted its worst day since June, with the Dow falling more than 800 points, the S&P 500 losing more than 3% and the Nasdaq more than 5%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: So yeah, while Wednesday looked good on the surface, Crisafulli's message is clear: don't get ahead of yourselves. This isn't necessarily a turning point yet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So yeah, while Wednesday looked good on the surface, Crisafulli's message is clear: don't get ahead of yourselves. This isn't necessarily a turning point yet.
